description: From Middle French subvention, from Late Latin subventio, from Latin subvenio (assist).

entries.meaning: A subsidy; provision of financial or other support.
examples: […]  the said religious shall  […]  pay all papal impositions, subventions, and contributions  […]

Now the only Ascension that we read of, besides these, is that of our blessed Saviour; and the Manner, in which he is said to have been carry’d up, was, by the Subvention of a Cloud, which rais’d him from the Ground  […]

entries.meaning: (archaic) The act of relieving, as of a burden; support; aid; assistance; help.
examples: […]  if we pray to God to remove a lesser judgement by way of subvention, questionlesse we may beseech him to deliver us from the great evill of a wounded conscience, by way of prevention.

verbs.description: subvention (third-person singular simple present subventions, present participle subventioning, simple past and past participle subventioned)

examples: His task was, it is true, made easier by the need of the English to remove troops to put down the 1745-6 Jacobite Rising, which the French had subventioned.
